title: 109_hr3450
content: The Act may be cited as the "Liberian Refugee Immigration Protection Act of 2005" and involves the adjustment of status of certain Liberian nationals. The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Protection Act of 2005" allows for the adjustment of status for eligible aliens to permanent residence, with specific criteria and deadlines outlined. The "Liberian Refugee Immigration Protection Act of 2005" allows eligible aliens with certain orders to apply for adjustment of status, without needing to file a motion to reopen the order. If the application is granted, the order is canceled; if denied, the order remains enforceable. Aliens eligible for adjustment of status under the "Liberian Refugee Immigration Protection Act of 2005" must be nationals of Liberia and have been granted temporary protected status on or after March 27, 1991. The Attorney General can provide a stay of removal for aliens with a final order of deportation or removal, allowing them to seek a stay based on the filing of an application under the Act. The Attorney General can authorize work for aliens in deportation proceedings who are eligible to apply for adjustment of status under the Act. If the application is pending for over 180 days without denial, the Attorney General must authorize employment. The Attorney General can authorize employment for aliens in deportation proceedings eligible for adjustment of status. Spouses and children of aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence can also have their status adjusted if they meet certain criteria. The Attorney General can authorize employment for aliens in deportation proceedings eligible for adjustment of status. Spouses and children of aliens lawfully admitted for permanent residence can also have their status adjusted if they meet certain criteria. To be eligible for adjustment of status, the alien must have been physically present in the United States for at least 1 year at the time of application, apply for adjustment while physically present in the US, be eligible for an immigration visa, and be admissible for permanent residence. Grounds for exclusion specified in certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act shall not apply. Proof of continuous physical presence is required to establish eligibility. An alien can maintain continuous physical presence for adjustment of status by not exceeding 180 days of absence from the US. The Attorney General must offer administrative review rights to applicants, similar to those under section 245 of the Immigration and Nationality Act or for aliens in removal proceedings under section 240. The Attorney General's decision on status adjustment is final and not subject to judicial review. The final decision on status adjustment under this section is not subject to judicial review. The Secretary of State is not required to reduce the number of immigrant visas available when an alien is granted permanent residence. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply, and the Attorney General's authority in immigration enforcement is not affected by this Act. The alien's eligibility for permanent residence under this section does not prevent them from seeking such status under other applicable laws.
